newsitem.title: USA: Florida senators ask USDA for freeze disaster aid.
newsitem.headline: Florida senators ask USDA for freeze disaster aid.

text.p: Florida's senators, Bob Graham and Connie Mack, asked the Agriculture Department to declare 20 counties disaster areas from a cold snap that destroyed an estimated $300 million worth of vegetables and fruits.
"This freeze was truly a disaster, with temperatures as low as 19 degrees Fahrenheit recorded as far south as Clewiston," the two senators wrote in a letter to USDA Secretary Dan Glickman.

Florida produces about half of all U.S. vegetables consumed during the winter months, and the state's growers sustained heavy losses of tomatoes, green beans, squash, bell peppers, eggplant and sweet corn. Citrus growers are still calculating the damage to groves from the Jan. 18-19 freeze.

The counties most affected from the freeze include Dade, Broward, Hillsborough and Orange, which are home to Miami, Fort Lauderdale, Tampa and Orlando, respectively. Other counties that reported extensive damage were Charlotte, Collier, Desoto, Glades, Hardee, Hendry, Highlands, Lake, Lee, Manatee, Okeechobee, Osceola, Palm Beach, Pasco, Polk and Sarasota.
Last week, Florida Gov. Lawton Chiles also asked the USDA to declare the 20 counties a disaster area.
